Chief Complaint: CHF/Afib with RVR
   24 Hour Events:
 PICC LINE - START [**2196-1-28**] 11:01 AM
   HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS: The patient is an 86y/o F with a PMH of
   CAD s/p CABG 86F with CAD s/p CABG [**10/2189**] (SVG-OM, LIMA-LAD), AS s/p
   valvuloplasty [**11-3**], diastolic CHF, AF on coumadin, s/p R colectomy
   [**12-6**] admitted with generalized tonic clonic seizure now transferred to
   the CCU for management of AF w/ RVR and pulmonary edema. Her recent
   past medical history inculdes an admission [**11-3**] for a history of
   worsening DOE with AS with valve area of 0.56cm2. She underwent
   valvuloplasty with subsequent diameter of 0.98cm2. Her course was
   complicated by LGI bleed and on colonoscopy a precancerous 2cm cecal
   polyp was found. She was then admitted from 1/11-20/10 for right
   hemicolectomy. Low-grade T2N0M0 well or moderately
   differentiatedadenocarcinoma. Her hospital course ([**2195-12-7**]- [**2195-12-16**])
   was complicated by hypercarbia requiring intubation and fluid overload
   requiring diuresis. Subsequent to this she developed C.
   difficile colitis, for which she has been on PO vancomycin since;
   she continued to complain of abdominal pain, with fevers post op
   and had a CT in [**2195-12-28**], that revealed slight increased fat
   stranding in the region of the sigmoid colon at sites of diverticula,
   representing a mild case of uncomplicated diverticulitis.
   .
   The patient was admitted on [**1-26**] to Neurology service after tonic clonic
   seizure activity which resolved spontaneously. Her daughter and husband
   were visiting her and they noticed a self-limitted 5 minutes seizure,
   described as acute onset of LOC, followed by whole body stiffens and
   later shaking. She was brought to the [**Hospital1 54**] ED, and during her
   observation in the ED she another 30 seconds GTC seizure. To stop the
   cluster she received Ativan IV and later she was loaded with 1000mg of
   IV Keppra. No further seizures in the ED. She was admitted to the Neuro
   ICU for further management. She was initially treated with broad
   spectrum abx including vancomycin/cipro/bactrim and acyclovir for
   concern for meningitis/encephalitis. These were stopped after approx 24
   hours. LP was not pursued given elevated INR on coumadin. CTA negative
   for CVA. She had no further seizure activity. MRI head demonstrated a
   focal area with high signal intensity in the right superior parietal
   lobule.
   .
   On evening of [**1-28**] the patient triggered for altered mental status and
   lethargy following head MRI. O2 sat found to be 84% and HR 130s, SBPs
   in 80s. Lasix 10mg IV given with no improvement. ABG 7.32/65/89/35.
   MICU consult was called and an additional 30mg IV lasix given with
   metoprolol 5mg IV. AMS felt most likely secondary to ativan given for
   head MRI. Repeat ABG this am 7.35/63/72/36. Given continued tachypnea
   and hypoxia requiring 4-5L NC, the patient was transferred to the CCU
   for further managment. Temp spiked to 101 and cultures sent.
   .
   .
   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
   1. CAD s/p CABG [**9-/2189**] for LM disease (LIMA to LAD and saphenous vein
   graft to the OM
   2. Severe AS s/p valvuloplasty in [**11-3**]
   3. AFib on coumadin
   4. HTN
   5. Hyperlipidemia
   6. OA, s/p R THR and spinal stenosis
   7. Squamous cell carcinoma
   8. Chronic venous stasis with ulcerations
   9. Hypothyroidism
   10. Peripheral neurophathy
   11. Raynaud
s syndrome
   12. R Retinal VA clot, w/ mild loss of vision
   13. Chronic Diastolic heart failure
   14. Shingles [**11-2**]
   13. Colon Cancer s/p hemicolectomy on [**2195-12-7**] course complicated by
   C.diff. Currently negative C. diff.
   .
   HOME MEDICATIONS:
   1. Furosemide 60mg daily
   2. Levothyroxine 75mg daily
   3.Latanoprost 0.005% drop daily
   4. Timoptic 0.5% drop daily
   5. Lipitor 40mg daily
   6. Gabapentin 300mg [**Hospital1 **]
   7. Coumadin 4mg [**Last Name (un) **]
   .
   MEDICATIONS ON TRANSFER:
   Glucagon 1 mg IM Q15MIN:PRN hypoglycemia protocol
   Insulin SC (per Insulin Flowsheet)
   Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO/NG Q6H:PRN pain\fever
   Ipratropium Bromide Neb 1 NEB IH Q6H
   Aspirin 81 mg PO/NG DAILY
   Latanoprost 0.005% Ophth. Soln. 1 DROP BOTH EYES HS
   Atorvastatin 40 mg PO/NG DAILY

   Bacitracin-Polymyxin Ointment 1 Appl TP Q6H:PRN wound
   LeVETiracetam 750 mg IV Q12H

   Dextrose 50% 12.5 gm IV PRN hypoglycemia protocol

   Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg PO/NG TID
   Famotidine 20 mg IV Q24H
   FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO/NG DAILY
   Nystatin Oral Suspension 5 mL PO QID:PRN [**Female First Name (un) 188**]
   Gabapentin 100 mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 **]
   Timolol Maleate 0.5% 1 DROP BOTH EYES DAILY
   .
   ALLERGIES: penicillin and erythromycin with rash and GI upset
   from Motrin
   .
   SOCIAL HISTORY
   [**Hospital **] [**Hospital **] rehab for 5 weeks.
   -Tobacco history:none
   -ETOH:none
   -Illicit drugs:none
   -uses walker/wheelchair at home, poor candidate for knee replacement.
   .
   FAMILY HISTORY:
   No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or sudden
   cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory.
   .
   PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
   VS: T=100.2 BP=123/66 HR= 87 RR= 21 O2 sat=95% on 4LNC
   GENERAL: responds to voice and painful stimuli, unable to follow
   commands.
   OPC/NC/AT/no LAD
   NECK: Supple with JVP of [**7-4**] cm in mid neck)
   CARDIAC: iirregularly irregular, [**3-1**] late peaking SEM heard, hear both
   S1 and S2 clearly, S2 may be fainter, throughout precordium, radiating
   to carotids.
   LUNGS: diffusely ronchorous, wheezing.
   ABDOMEN:+bs, soft, NT, obese.
   EXTREMITIES: 1+ pitting edema up to mid calf, bandages in place
   bilaterally in mid shin at site of presumed venous stasis ulcers.
   R/L DP/PT pulses weak,palpable, extremities WWP, good cap refill, skin
   turgor.
   .
   LABS/STUDIES
   EKG: [**2196-1-26**] in afib with rate varying between 100-150, nl axis. LVH:
   biphasic T waves in I, aVL. No waves seen.
   .
   2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM: [**2196-1-27**] - The left atrium is dilated. There is
   symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity
   size is normal. There is a mild resting left ventricular outflow tract
   obstruction. The aortic valve leaflets are severely thickened/deformed.
   Significant aortic stenosis is present (not quantified). Trace aortic
   regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are moderately
   thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic
   shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be significantly
   UNDERestimated.] The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened.
   There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no
   pericardial effusion.
   No vegetation seen (cannot definitively exclude).
   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2195-12-29**], a mild
   left ventricular outflow gradient is now detected.
   .
   CARDIAC CATH: [**2195-11-5**] - COMMENTS: 1) Coronary angiography in this
   right dominant system demonstrated two vessel disease. The LMCA was
   heavily calcified and had a 50-60% stenosis. The LAD was calcified and
   had a proximal 70% stenosis. The LCx was calcified and had a proximal
   50% stenosis. The RCA had mild lunen irregularities.
   2) Arterial conduit angiography revealed the LIMA to be widely patent.
   The SVG-OM1 had and 80% stenosis mid graft with TIMI 3 flow into the
   distal vessel.
   3) Resting hemodynamics revealed elvated right and left sided filling
   pressures with an RVEDP of 24 and LVEDP of 35mmHg. There was moderate
   to severe pulmonary arterial systolic hypertension with PASP of 68mmHg.
   The cardiac index was preserved at 3.26 l/min/m2. There was normal
   systemic arterial pressure with a BP of 136/73, mean 97mmHg.
   4) There was severe aortic stenosis with a peak to peak gradient of
   56mmHg and a calculated [**Location (un) **] of 0.56cm2. Following the Valvuloplasty the
   calculated [**Location (un) **] improved to 0.98cm2.
   5) Successful Aortic ballon valvuloplasty with a 20mm Tyshak balloon.
   (see PTCA comments for details)
   6) Unsuccessful Preclose of right femoral arteriotomy site.
   7) Successful closure of the right femoral arteriotomy site with an 8
   French Angioseal.
   FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
   1. Two vessel coronary artery disease.
   2. Severe aortic stenosis with a calculated [**Location (un) **] 0.56cm2
   3. Diseased SVG to OMB for staged PCI.
   4. Successful aortic balloon valvuloplasty to [**Location (un) **] 0.98cm2 .
   5. Unsuccessful closure with a Pre-close device.
   6. Successful closure with an Angioseal device.
   .
   RADIOLOGY: CXR [**1-28**] - Unchanged cardiomegaly with increased opacity in
   the left lower lobe concerning for pneumonia versus atelectasis. There
   is a small left pleural effusion unchanged. Fractures of the sternal
   wires are known and unchanged with no migration evident. The prior
   noted interstitial edema has now improved. There is persistent
   prominence of the bilateral pulmonary vasculature.
   IMPRESSION: Left lower lobe opacification may represent atelectasis
   versus pneumonia. Recommend clinical correlation.
   .
   HEAD MRI [**2196-1-28**] - IMPRESSION: 1. Focal area with high signal intensity
   is demonstrated at the right superior parietal lobule, with no
   significant mass effect and may represent a chronic hemorrhagic area.
   2. Subcortical areas with high signal intensity are identified on T2
   and FLAIR sequences, likely consistent with chronic microvascular
   ischemic changes.
   3. Tortuosity of the basilar artery, consistent with dolichoectasia,
   previously described by CTA on [**2196-1-26**].
   .
   EEG [**2196-1-27**] - This is an abnormal routine EEG in the waking and sleeping
   states due to a mildly slow and disorganized background as well as
   focal mild right temporal slowing throughout the recording. This
   background is consistent with a mild encephalopathy with focal
   dysfunction in the right temporal region. There were no epileptiform
   features noted
   .
   CTA HEAD [**2196-1-26**] - 1. No acute infarction or hemorrhage.
   2. Severe atherosclerotic narrowing of the distal right vertebral
   artery and moderate-to-severe narrowing of both cavernous internal
   carotid arteries. Small focus of calcification in the Basilar A. close
   to ithe tip. Given the extent of disease in the dominant right
   vertebral artery, associated vertebrobasilar insufficiency cannot be
   excluded. Further evlauation with MRA Neck with Gado can be considered
   for temporal info regarding the direction of flow, if there is no
   contra-indication to MRI.
   3. Moderate microangiopathic ischemic white matter disease
   .

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
   86 y/o female with hx CAD s/p CABG, Afib, with severe AS s/p
   valvuloplasty, diastolic CHF, colonic adenocarcinoma, chronic c.diff,
   admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures on [**2196-1-26**] who had MS
   change first noted following MRI, who subsequently flashed on the floor
   in the setting of holding lasix.
   .
   Afib: Pt in Afib with RVR on arrival. Had been NPO for some time on the
   floor, had been on p.o metoprolol on [**1-27**] am then changed to IV at 5-10
   Q4 on 3/3pm but didn't get any on [**1-28**] although written, ? [**12-29**] low SBPs.
   On arrival to floor received IV metoprolol 2.5 with improvement rate to
   80's from 128.
   Uptitrated metoprolol to 15mg IV q4 (conversion 2.5:1 IV to p.o)
   -continue metoprolol IV.
   As becomes more alert, able to tolerate pills convert to p.o.
   -am EKG.
   # Flash Pulmonary Edema: CAD s/p CABG 86F with CAD s/p CABG [**10/2189**]
   (SVG-OM, LIMA-LAD)
   -Given AS pt very sensitive to fluid shifts, had been lying down for a
   long time at MRI and lasix was being held on floor to prevent cerebral
   hypoperfusion with subsequent flash.
   On arrival to ICU received IV lasix bolus 60mg IV and started on lasix
   drip.
   Continue lasix drip, titrating based on clinical appearance/respiratory
   status.
   -On digoxin chronically, typically not preferred in setting of normal
   EF, will continue for now. Dig level 0.9 (range 0.9-2)
   -repeat ABG this pm
   -repeat CXR in am.
   .
   #AS: AS s/p valvuloplasty [**11-3**].Severe AS on Echo [**2196-1-27**] with valve
   area not quantified but LVOT of 12 noted which was not noted on Echo of
   [**12-29**] but valve area of 0.8. EF stable at 60%. AS known critical, unclear
   if worsened AS since [**Month (only) **] as valve area not quantified but known to be
   critical. Pt poor surgical candidate thus had not received AVR.
   -Consideration being given for minimally invasive percutaneous valve
   replacement.
   -f/u with ICU fellow/Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 8906**]
   [**Name (STitle) 1658**] cautious diruesis in setting critical AS.
   .
   # MS Change: Likely multifactorial related to benzodiazepine pre MRI
   although only received 0.5mg, C02 retention [**12-29**] fatigue with mildly
   elevated C02 of 63 on ABG, and low CO with CHF.
   Did have [**Doctor Last Name 11764**] on CTA and has new, subtle LUE/LLE weakness and no
   reflexes on LLE which is new per neuro consistent with lesion on right.
   This lesion is most likely vascular in nature, either a small infarct
   which converted to a bleed, versus less likely malignant ? metastatic
   colon cancer. Once medically stable neuro recommends MRI with
   gadolinium to asses lesion. If does not enhance, likely bleed.
   -appreciate neuro recs
   -ASA 81mg
   -serial neuro exams.
   -keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
   -gentle diuresis
   -avoid benzos
   -follow resp status, serial ABGs.
   -diuresis
   .
   # ? Infection: Pt low grade temp to 100.3.
   Had been lying flat at MRI y/d, possible aspiration pneumonitis.
   If spikes temp, white count, institute Abx coverage with cipro.
   f/u with [**Hospital1 **] ? chronic suppression with vanc for c.diff
   Blood cx drawn with initial question of meningitis on presentation with
   seizures have been negative x 3. Urine cx negative x1, repeat drawn on
   [**2196-1-29**] pending.
   -f/u final urine cx
   -trend WBC, fever curve.
   .
   # Hx Diarrhea:
   hx C.diff on chronic suppression therapy with p.o vanc/flagyll with
   last cx at [**Hospital **] rehab on [**2196-1-15**] negative but abx were continued to
   continued diarrhea. However diarrhea has stopped so abx stopped this
   hospitalization.
   Continue to monitor.
   .
   #hx GI bleed: s/p hemicolectomy following which she presented to [**Hospital 12**]
   rehab.
   Baseline Hct ~ 30, 35 on [**3-5**] now 32.2
   Continue to trend daily.
   Guiac all stools
   active type and screen.
   .
   FEN:
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx: holding given INR 5.0
   -Pain management with tylenol/gabapentin
   -Bowel regimen: hold
   .

   .

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation (AFib), and severe aortic stenosis (AS) post-valvuloplasty. She was admitted to the ICU with a new onset of tonic-clonic seizures and altered mental status. She has a history of chronic diarrhea and C. difficile colitis, and is currently on chronic suppression therapy with vancomycin.

Physical Examination:

* Vital signs: T=100.2, BP=123/66, HR=87, RR=21, O2 sat=95%
* General: responds to voice and painful stimuli, unable to follow commands
* Cardiac: irregularly irregular rhythm, late peaking S1 and S2, radiating to carotids
* Lungs: diffusely ronchorous, wheezing
* Abdomen: soft, non-tender, obese
* Extremities: 1+ pitting edema up to mid-calf, bandages in place bilaterally in mid-shin at site of presumed venous stenosis ulcers

Laboratory Data:

* WBC: 11.7 K/uL
* Hct: 34.7%
* Plt: 500 K/uL
* Cr: 0.8 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.02 ng/mL
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 28.2/30.6/2.8, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 15/0.02/0.02, ALT/AST: 5-13, Alk Phos/T Bili: 62/0.2, Amylase/Lipase: 47/0.2

Assessment and Plan:

* Aortic Stenosis: severe AS on echo with valve area not quantified, EF stable at 60%
* Seizure: likely multifactorial, considering benzodiazepine pre-MRI, CO2 retention, fatigue, and low CO with CHF
* MS Change: likely multifactorial, considering benzodiazepine pre-MRI, CO2 retention, fatigue, and low CO with CHF
* Infection: low-grade temp to 100.3, possible aspiration pneumonitis, pending urine cx and blood cx
* Hx Diarrhea: chronic suppression therapy with vancomycin, diarrhea has stopped
* Hx GI bleed: s/p hemicolectomy, baseline Hct ~ 30, 35 on [**3-5**] now 32.2

Potential Medical Complications:

* Worsening aortic stenosis
* Infection (C. difficile, pneumonia, or other)
* GI bleed
* Seizure recurrence
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac failure
* Neurological compromise

Recommendations:

* Continue metoprolol IV, titrating based on clinical appearance/respiratory status
* Repeat ABG this pm and CXR in am
* Consideration for minimally invasive percutaneous valve replacement
* Gentle diuresis, avoiding benzos, and following respiratory status
* Serial neuro exams, ASA 81mg, and keppra for seizure prophylaxis
* Trend WBC, fever curve, and monitor for signs of infection
* Continue to monitor GI bleeding and diarrhea
* Repeat urine cx and blood cx as pending
* F/u with neuro regarding MRI with gadolinium to assess lesion
* F/u with ICU fellow/Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 8906**] regarding minimally invasive percutaneous valve replacement.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, previous coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), and severe aortic stenosis (AS) with chronic heart failure. She was admitted with new onset tonic-clonic seizures and was found to have a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) change in her brain. She has been febrile, with a temperature of 101.8°F, and has been experiencing respiratory distress, which is suspected to be due to aspiration or hospital-acquired pneumonia.

The patient has been receiving treatment for her respiratory distress, including antibiotics and diuretics. She has also been receiving treatment for her seizures, including medication and prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory distress and fever may be indicative of pneumonia, which could be hospital-acquired or aspiration-related.
2. Flash pulmonary edema: The patient's history of severe AS and chronic heart failure makes her susceptible to flash pulmonary edema, which could be exacerbated by fluid shifts and decreased cardiac output.
3. Vascular events: The patient's MRI change and subtle left upper extremity weakness may indicate a vascular event, such as a small infarct or bleed, which could be related to her underlying cardiovascular disease.
4. Malignancy: The patient's history of colon cancer and the presence of a lesion on her brain MRI may indicate a potential recurrence of her cancer.
5. C. difficile infection: The patient's history of C. difficile infection and diarrhea may indicate a recurrence of the infection, which could be exacerbated by her underlying medical conditions.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and hemicolectomy may indicate a potential recurrence of bleeding, which could be exacerbated by her underlying medical conditions.
7. Seizure prophylaxis: The patient's seizure prophylaxis medication may need to be adjusted or discontinued if she becomes more alert and able to take oral medication.
8. Fluid management: The patient's fluid management may need to be adjusted to prevent fluid overload and worsening of her respiratory distress.
9. Pain management: The patient's pain management may need to be adjusted to ensure adequate pain control without exacerbating her respiratory distress.
10. Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis: The patient's prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis may need to be adjusted or discontinued if her international normalized ratio (INR) becomes elevated.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old female with a history of decompensated Stage IV CHF, who was admitted for inotropic-assisted diuresis with superimposed sepsis. She is intubated for hypercarbic respiratory failure and airway protection. The patient's condition has been complicated by pneumonia, aspiration, aortic stenosis, and seizure activity without status epilepticus.

Recent events include:

* Fever of 101.8°F
* TEE performed showing no vegetations on valves or RV/RA wires, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation
* PA catheter pulled, tip not sent
* Swan numbers: 35, 13, 5.7, 2.8, 841
* Labs showed worsening metabolic alkalosis, stable respiratory alkalosis
* Started on acetazolamide x 2 doses in addition to K/Phos repletions
* Held Lasix due to hypotension, restarted with UOP ~ 200cc/hr achieved with Lasix drip at 10cc/hr
* Had 32-beat run of VT with K of 2.9, agitated, K repleted
* Continued diarrhea, C. difficile positive, guaiac positive

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's low-grade fever and stable white count suggest that sepsis may not be ongoing, but the presence of MRSA in the sputum and blood culture raises concerns for endocarditis.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure is likely multifactorial, with pneumonia being one component. The presence of aspiration pneumonia and C. difficile diarrhea suggests that the patient's respiratory failure may be worsened by gastrointestinal complications.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's aortic stenosis and decompensated CHF make her susceptible to cardiac complications, including cardiogenic shock, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's seizure activity and abnormal mental status raise concerns for neurological complications, including intracranial processes such as hydrocephalus or stroke.
5. Renal complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease and hypovolemia make her susceptible to renal complications, including acute kidney injury and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's C. difficile diarrhea and guaiac positive stools suggest that she may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, including bowel perforation and sepsis.
7. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension and need for pressor support suggest that she may be at risk for hemodynamic instability, including cardiogenic shock and hypovolemic shock.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old female admitted to the ICU for inotropic-assisted diuresis with superimposed sepsis, now intubated for hypercarbic respiratory failure/airway protection. The patient has a complex medical history, including decompensated Stage IV CHF, aortic stenosis, and a history of cardiomyopathy with an implanted ICD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Fever: 101.8°F
* TEE showed no vegetations on valves or RV/RA wires, with mild to moderate mitral regurgitation
* Swan numbers: 35, 13, 5.7, 2.8, 841
* Labs showed worsening metabolic alkalosis, stable respiratory alkalosis
* Patient is on multiple medications, including vasopressin, Lasix, and antibiotics

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Cardiogenic shock due to CHF
	* Hypotension due to vasopressor use
	* Atrial fibrillation with frequent ectopy
	* Potential for VT or VF
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia with possible sepsis
	* Hypercarbic respiratory failure
	* Risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
3. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypoperfusion
	* Potential for worsening renal function with continued diuresis
4. Neurological complications:
	* Seizure activity with low potassium levels
	* Potential for intracranial process or hydrocephalus
	* Risk of increased intracranial pressure (ICP)
5. Infectious complications:
	* Sepsis due to MRSA or Proteus mirabilis
	* Risk of further infection with continued antibiotics
6. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Diarrhea with possible Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection
	* Risk of further gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications. The ICU team should continue to optimize the patient's cardiac function, manage her respiratory status, and address any potential infections or gastrointestinal issues.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old female with a complex medical history, including decompensated Stage IV CHF, sepsis, pneumonia, and aspiration. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for intubation and mechanical ventilation due to hypercarbic respiratory failure and airway protection.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 101.8°F (38.8°C)
* Blood pressure: 103/51 mmHg
* Heart rate: 87 beats per minute
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 500 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
* Lactate: 34 mmol/L
* Electrolytes: Na+ 139 mmol/L, K+ 2.9 mmol/L, Cl- 100 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Pneumonia
* Aspiration
* Aortic stenosis
* Seizure
* Cardiogenic shock
* Hypothyroidism
* Hypervolemic hyponatremia
* Elevated lactate
* Cardiac risk factors (LDL 69, HbA1c 6.6)

The patient's current medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix)
* Acetazolamide
* K/Phos repletions
* Vasopressin
* Metoprolol
* Famotidine (Pepcid)
* Metronidazole
* Cefipime
* Vancomycin
* Acyclovir
* Bactrim (SMX/TMP)

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued intubation and mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure
* Pressor support to maintain blood pressure and cerebral perfusion
* Hemodynamic support with vasopressin and dobutamine
* Antibiotic therapy with cefipime and vancomycin
* Antifungal therapy with fluconazole
* Anti-seizure medication with phenytoin
* Pain management with morphine and fentanyl
* Electrolyte repletions as needed
* Daily neuro exams and imaging studies to monitor for intracranial processes

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia progression and respiratory failure
* Cardiogenic shock and cardiac arrest
* Sepsis and septic shock
* Aspiration and respiratory failure
* Hypothyroidism and hypothyroid crisis
* Hypervolemic hyponatremia and seizures
* Elevated lactate and lactic acidosis
* Cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest
* Infection and sepsis with antibiotic-resistant bacteria
* Neurological deterioration and intracranial hemorrhage

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions and potential complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications and ensure the patient's optimal outcome.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old female with decompensated Stage IV CHF, admitted for inotropic-assisted diuresis with superimposed sepsis, now intubated for hypercarbic respiratory failure/airway protection.

The patient has been experiencing a range of medical complications, including:

1. Fever: The patient's temperature has been elevated to 101.8°F (38.8°C) with a recent spike to 102°F (39°C) at 10:00 PM. This may indicate an ongoing infection.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a low-grade fever and swan numbers prior to DC arguing against current ongoing sepsis. However, MRSA cultured from sputum and blood-vanc sensitive, and sparse growth Proteus mirabilis from sputum sensitive to cefepime, suggesting a potential septic process.
3. Pneumonia: The patient has been intubated for hypercarbic respiratory failure/airway protection, and there is a possibility of pneumonia as a contributing factor.
4. Aortic stenosis: The patient has a history of chronic right and left-sided systolic heart failure, which may be exacerbated by the septic process.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has had episodes of atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia, which may be related to electrolyte imbalances or cardiac dysfunction.
6. Renal dysfunction: The patient has a creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL, which may indicate kidney damage or dysfunction.
7. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has a pH level of 7.42, which may be related to respiratory or metabolic causes.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is currently taking Synthroid.
9. Cardiac risk factors: The patient has a history of LDL 69 and HbA1c 6.6, which may be contributing to her cardiac dysfunction.
10. Neurological symptoms: The patient has anisocoria and sluggish mental status, which may be related to hypoxia, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.

The patient's current medications include:

1. Furosemide (Lasix) for diuresis
2. Acetazolamide for metabolic alkalosis
3. K/Phos repletions for electrolyte imbalances
4. Vancomycin for septicemia
5. Cefepime for pneumonia
6. Metronidazole for suspected C. difficile infection
7. Dobutamine for cardiac support
8. Vasopressin for pressor support
9. Heparin for anticoagulation
10. Aspirin for cardiac risk reduction
11. Zocor for cholesterol management
12. Synthroid for hypothyroidism

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue diuresis with Lasix drip and boluses as needed
2. Monitor and manage sepsis with antibiotics and pressor support
3. Continue respiratory support with mechanical ventilation
4. Manage cardiac arrhythmias with electrolyte repletions and anti-arrhythmic medications
5. Monitor and manage renal dysfunction with diuretics and electrolyte repletions
6. Continue thyroid replacement therapy with Synthroid
7. Monitor and manage neurological symptoms with daily neuro exams and electrolyte repletions

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac arrest
2. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction
3. Respiratory failure
4. Renal failure
5. Neurological deterioration
6. Electrolyte imbalances
7. Infection-related complications
8. Cardiovascular complications
9. Metabolic acidosis or alkalosis
10. Hypothyroidism-related complications

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and severe aortic stenosis who was admitted with new-onset tonic-clonic seizures. She has been diagnosed with a multifactorial change in her mental status, possibly related to benzodiazepine pre-MRI, carbon dioxide retention, fatigue, and low CO with CHF. The patient has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and desaturation, and has been treated with antibiotics for possible hospital-acquired pneumonia and aspiration. She has also been diagnosed with chronic c.diff and has a history of GI bleed and diarrhea.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with intermittent desaturation and requirement for supplemental oxygen. Further monitoring and treatment may be necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and tachycardia may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death if not promptly treated.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and severe aortic stenosis increases her risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's history of seizures and altered mental status increases her risk of neurological complications, such as stroke, cerebral edema, and seizure recurrence.
5. Infection: The patient's history of chronic c.diff and possible hospital-acquired pneumonia increases her risk of infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
6. GI complications: The patient's history of GI bleed and diarrhea increases her risk of GI complications, such as bleeding, perforation, and malnutrition.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's history of CHF and severe aortic stenosis increases her risk of fluid overload, which could lead to cardiac complications and worsening of her respiratory status.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Continue to treat the patient's fever and tachycardia with antibiotics and other medications as necessary to prevent sepsis.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent neurological complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's GI status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent GI complications.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent fluid overload.
7. Consider minimally invasive percutaneous valve replacement for the patient's severe aortic stenosis.
8. Consider MRI with gadolinium to assess the patient's lesion on the right side of her brain.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further deterioration.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent seizure recurrence.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, Afib, severe AS, and chronic c.diff. She was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures and was found to have a MS change on MRI, which is likely multifactorial related to benzodiazepine pre-MRI, C02 retention, and low CO with CHF. She has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and desaturation, and has been treated with antibiotics, lasix, and metoprolol. She has also been experiencing diarrhea and has a history of C.diff.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and desaturation may be indicative of pneumonia, which is a common complication in ICU patients.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's desaturation and need for oxygen therapy may be indicative of ARDS, which is a life-threatening complication in ICU patients.
3. Sepsis: The patient's fever and tachycardia may be indicative of sepsis, which is a life-threatening complication in ICU patients.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of CAD and Afib, as well as her current tachycardia, may increase her risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of C.diff and diarrhea may increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's MS change on MRI may be indicative of a neurological complication such as a stroke or a seizure disorder.
7. Renal Complications: The patient's history of chronic c.diff and her current use of lasix may increase her risk of renal complications such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
8. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's history of CAD and CHF, as well as her current desaturation, may increase her risk of pulmonary edema, which is a life-threatening complication in ICU patients.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, oxygen saturation, and blood gases to assess for any changes in her condition.
2. Continue to treat the patient's fever, tachycardia, and desaturation with antibiotics, lasix, and metoprolol as necessary.
3. Consider performing a repeat CT scan to assess for any changes in the patient's MS change on MRI.
4. Consider performing a repeat ECG to assess for any changes in the patient's Afib.
5. Consider performing a repeat echocardiogram to assess for any changes in the patient's cardiac function.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider performing a repeat stool test to assess for any changes in her C.diff status.
7. Consider performing a repeat neurological examination to assess for any changes in the patient's MS change on MRI.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider performing a repeat blood test to assess for any changes in her kidney function.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, severe aortic stenosis, colonic adenocarcinoma, and chronic Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection. She was admitted to the ICU with new onset tonic-clonic seizures and was found to have a multifactorial seizure disorder.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is receiving oxygen via nasal cannula and has a SpO2 of 98%. Her ABG results show a pH of 7.36, pCO2 of 60 mmHg, and pO2 of 73 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 93 bpm and a blood pressure of 115/52 mmHg. She has a history of coronary artery disease and severe aortic stenosis.
* Neurological status: The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10 and is disoriented to person, time, and place. She has weakness in her left upper extremity and no reflexes in her left lower extremity, which may indicate a vascular lesion.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has a history of diarrhea and C. diff infection, which has been treated with antibiotics. She is currently on a low-fiber diet and is receiving IV fluids.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine level is 0.8 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 33 mg/dL.
* Hematological status: The patient's white blood cell count (WBC) is 11.7 x 10^9/L, and her platelet count is 354 x 10^9/L.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Pulmonary edema: Given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and severe aortic stenosis, she is at risk for pulmonary edema.
2. Flash pulmonary edema: The patient's recent history of lying flat at MRI and the holding of lasix may have contributed to flash pulmonary edema.
3. Seizure disorder: The patient's seizure disorder may worsen or become more frequent if not properly managed.
4. Infection: The patient's low-grade fever and recent history of C. diff infection may indicate a potential infection.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and recent diarrhea may indicate a risk for further bleeding.
6. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is slightly elevated, which may indicate early signs of renal failure.
7. Neurological deterioration: The patient's weakness in her left upper extremity and lack of reflexes in her left lower extremity may indicate a worsening neurological condition.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions and potential complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications and ensure the patient's overall well-being.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and severe aortic stenosis who was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures. She has been experiencing flash pulmonary edema, and her condition is complicated by chronic diarrhea caused by Clostridioides difficile (C. diff). She has also been experiencing mild elevation of carbon dioxide levels and low CO2 levels, which may be related to her chronic C. diff infection. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 93 beats per minute, blood pressure of 115/52 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. She is receiving IV lasix and metoprolol, and her wound care plan includes rheum consultation when her condition improves.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Fluid overload: The patient's flash pulmonary edema and low CO2 levels may indicate fluid overload, which can lead to further respiratory distress and cardiovascular instability.
2. C. diff infection: The patient's chronic diarrhea and mild elevation of carbon dioxide levels may indicate a persistent C. diff infection, which can lead to further complications such as sepsis and organ failure.
3. Aortic stenosis: The patient's severe aortic stenosis may worsen over time, leading to further cardiovascular instability and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's seizure history and mild elevation of carbon dioxide levels may indicate neurological complications, which can lead to further neurological deficits and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. GI bleeding: The patient's history of GI bleeding and chronic diarrhea may indicate ongoing bleeding, which can lead to further complications such as anemia and potentially life-threatening bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's low-grade temperature and possible aspiration pneumonitis may indicate an infection, which can lead to further complications such as sepsis and organ failure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust IV lasix and metoprolol as needed to prevent fluid overload.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's C. diff infection and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further complications.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's aortic stenosis and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further cardiovascular instability.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further neurological deficits.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's GI bleeding and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further complications.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's infection and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a complex medical history and multiple comorbidities.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure of 115/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia (Hb 8.8 g/dL), thrombocytopenia (Platelet count 34.7 x 10^9/L), and elevated lactate (20 mg/dL). The patient's liver enzymes are mildly elevated, with an ALT of 13 IU/L and an AST of 5 IU/L.

The patient's medical conditions include impaired skin integrity, pneumonia, aortic stenosis, and seizure disorder. The patient is also at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

The patient's current medications include furosemide (Lasix), metoprolol, famotidine (Pepcid), and regular insulin sliding scale.

The patient's plan includes wound care, antibiotic therapy, and management of their underlying medical conditions. The patient is also at risk for further complications, including sepsis, multi-organ failure, and cardiac arrest.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's impaired skin integrity and pneumonia, there is a high risk of sepsis.
2. Multi-organ failure: The patient's underlying medical conditions, including aortic stenosis and seizure disorder, increase the risk of multi-organ failure.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's aortic stenosis and atrial fibrillation increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
4. VAP: The patient's mechanical ventilation and risk factors for VAP increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
5. DVT: The patient's immobility and risk factors for DVT increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis.
6. Liver failure: The patient's mildly elevated liver enzymes increase the risk of liver failure.
7. Kidney failure: The patient's anemia and elevated lactate levels increase the risk of kidney failure.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   admission.  She is currently on a lasix gtt.  Her respiratory status

   any new infiltrate though
   - trend WBC and fever curves
   - f/u micro data
   # Afib: Pt in Afib with RVR on arrival, in the setting of not receiving
   her metoprolol. Restarted on IV metoprolol on arrival to the CCU.  Now
   s/p transition to PO metprolol.
   - no episodes RVR overnight

   critical, unclear if worsened AS since [**Month (only) **] as valve area not quantified
   but known to be critical. Pt poor surgical candidate thus had not
   received AVR.
   - consideration being given for minimally invasive percutaneous valve
   replacement
   #  MS Change: Likely multifactorial related to benzodiazepine,
   infection, ?stroke.
   - ASA 81mg
   - serial neuro exams.
   - keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
   - avoid benzos
   - follow resp status, serial ABGs.
   - diuresis and antibiotics as above
   - MRI when stable, per neuro recs
   # Hx Diarrhea: Hx C.diff on chronic suppression therapy with p.o
   vanc/flagyl with last cx at [**Hospital **] rehab on [**2196-1-15**] negative. At that
   time, antibiotics were continued. However diarrhea has stopped so abx
   stopped this hospitalization.
   - can continue to monitor
   - f/u stool studies sent yesterday
   # hx GI bleed: Hematocrit stable this morning
   - continue to trend hematocrit

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease (CAD) with previous coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), atrial fibrillation (Afib), severe aortic stenosis (AS) following valvuloplasty, diastolic heart failure, and colonic adenocarcinoma. She was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures and was found to have a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) change, which was initially thought to be a stroke.

The patient's current condition is stable, with improved respiratory status since transfer to the cardiac care unit (CCU). She is receiving lasix drip for pulmonary edema and has been started on antibiotics for possible aspiration pneumonia. She is also being treated for atrial fibrillation with metoprolol and is being monitored for stroke.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pulmonary edema: The patient's history of severe AS and diastolic heart failure increases her risk of developing pulmonary edema, which can lead to respiratory failure.
2. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's history of chronic C. difficile infection and recent antibiotic use increases her risk of developing aspiration pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.
3. Stroke: The patient's recent MRI change and history of Afib increase her risk of developing a stroke, which can lead to neurological deficits and death.
4. Seizures: The patient's history of seizures and recent MRI change increase her risk of developing further seizures, which can lead to neurological deficits and death.
5. GI bleeding: The patient's history of GI bleeding and recent antibiotic use increases her risk of developing further GI bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and death.
6. Infection: The patient's history of chronic C. difficile infection and recent antibiotic use increases her risk of developing further infections, which can lead to sepsis and death.

The patient's current medications include:

* Lasix drip for pulmonary edema
* Metoprolol for atrial fibrillation
* Antibiotics for possible aspiration pneumonia
* Keppra for seizure prophylaxis
* H2 blocker for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control

The patient's lab results include:

* Hemoglobin: 11.7 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 34.7%
* Platelet count: 54.1 x 10^3/μL
* White blood cell count: 11.7 x 10^3/μL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 20 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
* Lactate dehydrogenase: 202 IU/L

The patient's vital signs include:

* Temperature: 37.6°C (99.6°F)
* Heart rate: 93 bpm
* Blood pressure: 115/52 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths/min
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* SpO2: 98%

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Alert and oriented to person, but disoriented to place and time
* EOMI (eyes move in irregularly) and PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Irregular rhythm and holosystolic murmur throughout the chest
* Significant wheezes and rhonchi throughout the lungs
* Wet cough
* Waffle boots in place

The patient's diagnosis is complex and multifactorial, and her treatment plan should be individualized based on her specific needs and medical history.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, Afib, and severe AS, who was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures and flash pulmonary edema. The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential medical complications.

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient has a history of severe AS and developed pulmonary edema in the setting of having her diuretics held on admission. She is currently on a lasix drip, and her respiratory status has improved greatly since transfer to the CCU. However, there is a risk of recurrent pulmonary edema due to the patient's critical AS.
2. Afib: The patient is in Afib with RVR, which is a significant risk factor for stroke and other cardiac complications. The patient's blood pressure has been fluctuating, and she has received IV metoprolol to control her heart rate.
3. Flash Pulmonary Edema: The patient's flash pulmonary edema is likely related to her critical AS and the holding of diuretics on admission. There is a risk of recurrent flash pulmonary edema if the patient's fluid status is not carefully managed.
4. MS Change: The patient has a new, subtle LUE/LLE weakness and no reflexes on LLE, which is consistent with a lesion on the right side. This lesion is likely vascular in nature, either a small infarct or a bleed. The patient's neurologist recommends an MRI with gadolinium to assess the lesion.
5. Infection: The patient has a low-grade temperature, which may be related to aspiration pneumonitis or a urinary tract infection. If her temperature spikes, she will require antibiotics coverage with cipro.
6. Hx Diarrhea: The patient has a history of C. diff and has been on chronic suppression therapy with p.o. vanc/flagyll. Her diarrhea has stopped, but she will need to be monitored for recurrence.
7. Hx GI Bleed: The patient has a history of GI bleed and is at risk for recurrent bleeding. She will need to be monitored for signs of bleeding and have her stool guaiac tested regularly.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Recurrent pulmonary edema due to critical AS and fluid overload.
2. Stroke or other cardiac complications due to Afib and critical AS.
3. Recurrent flash pulmonary edema due to fluid overload and critical AS.
4. Neurological deficits or worsening of existing deficits due to the patient's MS change.
5. Infection or sepsis due to aspiration pneumonitis or urinary tract infection.
6. Recurrence of diarrhea or C. diff due to chronic suppression therapy.
7. Recurrent GI bleed due to underlying disease and medications.

The patient's management should focus on carefully managing her fluid status, controlling her Afib, and monitoring her neurological status. She should also be closely monitored for signs of infection or bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, severe aortic stenosis, atrial fibrillation, and colonic adenocarcinoma. She was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures and was found to have a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) change in her brain. She has a history of chronic C. difficile infection and has been treated with antibiotics. She is currently on a lasix drip, digoxin, and antibiotics, and is being monitored for pulmonary edema, aspiration pneumonia, and atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's history of severe aortic stenosis and diastolic heart failure puts her at risk for developing pulmonary edema. Her current treatment with lasix and digoxin may help alleviate this condition, but further monitoring is necessary to ensure that her respiratory status remains stable.
2. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient's recent fever and lack of leukocytosis suggest that she may be at risk for developing aspiration pneumonia. Her current antibiotics and continued monitoring of her WBC and fever curves may help prevent this complication.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is being managed with metoprolol, but further monitoring is necessary to ensure that her heart rhythm remains stable.
4. Myocardial Infarction: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and atrial fibrillation puts her at risk for developing a myocardial infarction. Her current treatment with aspirin and beta blockers may help reduce this risk.
5. C. difficile Infection: The patient's history of chronic C. difficile infection and recent treatment with antibiotics may put her at risk for developing a recurrence of this infection. Further monitoring of her stool studies and continued treatment with antibiotics may help prevent this complication.
6. GI Bleed: The patient's history of GI bleed and current treatment with anticoagulants may put her at risk for developing another GI bleed. Further monitoring of her hematocrit and continued treatment with anticoagulants may help prevent this complication.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's recent MRI change in her brain and history of seizures put her at risk for developing neurological complications. Further monitoring of her neurological status and continued treatment with anticonvulsants may help prevent this complication.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, post-CABG, atrial fibrillation, severe aortic stenosis, and colonic adenocarcinoma. She was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures and was found to have a change in mental status (MS) following an MRI. She has been diagnosed with chronic C. difficile and has a history of diarrhea, GI bleed, and hemicolectomy.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Flash Pulmonary Edema:** Given the patient's history of CAD, CABG, and severe AS, she is at high risk for flash pulmonary edema, which has already been observed.
2. **Critical AS:** The patient's severe AS is critical, and further deterioration could lead to heart failure and death.
3. **Cerebral Hypoperfusion:** The patient's history of lying flat at MRI and holding Lasix could lead to cerebral hypoperfusion, which may worsen her MS.
4. **Infection:** The patient's low-grade fever and possible aspiration pneumonitis raise concerns for infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
5. **Seizure Prophylaxis:** The patient's history of seizures and current use of keppra for seizure prophylaxis may not be sufficient to prevent further seizures.
6. **GI Bleed:** The patient's history of GI bleed and chronic C. difficile could lead to further bleeding episodes.
7. **Diabetes Mellitus:** The patient's current use of insulin sliding scale for glycemic control may not be sufficient to manage her blood sugar levels, especially in the setting of critical illness.
8. **Vascular Compromise:** The patient's history of LUE/LLE weakness and no reflexes on LLE suggests potential vascular compromise, which may worsen her MS and increase the risk of further complications.

**Plan:**

1. Continue metoprolol IV and titrate based on clinical appearance and respiratory status.
2. Monitor the patient's MS and adjust treatment as needed.
3. Repeat ABG and CXR as ordered.
4. Continue Lasix drip and titrate based on clinical appearance and respiratory status.
5. Monitor the patient's temperature and white count and institute Abx coverage with cipro if necessary.
6. Repeat urine cx and trend WBC and fever curve.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's GI status and trend Hct daily.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's neuro status and consider MRI with gadolinium to assess the lesion on her right side.
9. Consider minimally invasive percutaneous valve replacement for her severe AS.
10. Continue to monitor the patient's overall condition and adjust treatment as needed to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, aortic stenosis, atrial fibrillation, and colon cancer. She was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures, likely related to aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She has improved significantly since transfer to the CCU, now on 2L NC oxygen and tolerating humidified face mask. Her pulmonary edema has improved, and she is still requiring diuresis.
* Cardiovascular: She has a history of severe aortic stenosis, which has not been quantified since her valvuloplasty. She is in atrial fibrillation, but her rate is well-controlled in the 80s. She is taking IV metoprolol and has been transitioned to PO metoprolol.
* Neurological: She has anisocoria, which may be related to recent neb treatment or a recent stroke. She is at risk for seizures and is taking keppra for prophylaxis.
* Gastrointestinal: She has a history of chronic c. diff, which has been suppressed with PO vanc/flagyl. However, she has stopped taking antibiotics and her diarrhea has resolved.
* Hematological: Her hematocrit is stable, and she is at risk for GI bleed.
* Skin integrity: She has venous stasis ulcers, which are being treated with bandaging.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still compromised, and she may require further interventions to improve her oxygenation and ventilation.
* Cardiac arrest: Given her history of severe aortic stenosis and atrial fibrillation, she is at risk for cardiac arrest.
* Seizure: The patient is at risk for seizures, especially given her anisocoria and history of seizures.
* GI bleed: The patient's history of chronic c. diff and GI bleed puts her at risk for further GI bleeding.
* Skin breakdown: The patient's venous stasis ulcers may worsen if not properly treated.
* Infection: The patient is at risk for further infections, especially given her compromised immune system and history of aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning off oxygen as tolerated
* Continuing lasix drip and titrating as needed
* Continuing atrovent nebs and dextromorphan PRN cough
* Repeating CXR today
* Monitoring WBC and fever curves
* Continuing vanc/cefepime/flagyll antibiotics
* Considering adding zosyn
* Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure
* Monitoring for signs of cardiac arrest
* Monitoring for signs of seizure activity
* Monitoring for signs of GI bleed
* Monitoring for signs of skin breakdown
* Monitoring for signs of infection

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a diagnosis of aspiration pneumonia, treated with antibiotics, and continued on a lasix drip for diuresis. The patient's temperature defervesced from 101°F to 99°F after blood and urine cultures were sent. Pyuria was noted on urine analysis, and culture data is pending. The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins, erythromycin, and latex. They are also experiencing diarrhea, with a C. difficile toxin-negative result. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, blood pressure in the low 100s systolic, and respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. The patient's physical examination reveals bilateral crackles, and they are able to follow commands but are disoriented to time.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and pyuria may indicate a septic episode, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not promptly treated.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's aspiration pneumonia may worsen if not properly treated, leading to respiratory failure and increased risk of secondary infections.
3. Diarrhea: The patient's diarrhea, despite a C. difficile toxin-negative result, may indicate a gastrointestinal infection or inflammatory process, which could lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances if not managed appropriately.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's aortic stenosis and atrial fibrillation may increase their risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and stroke.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's anisocoria and left-sided weakness may indicate a neurological complication, such as a stroke or seizure, which could worsen if not promptly treated.
6. Venous Stasis Ulcers: The patient's venous stasis ulcers may worsen if not properly managed, leading to increased risk of infection and poor wound healing.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's continued use of lasix and other diuretics may increase their risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, and constipation.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status to prevent complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and severe aortic stenosis, who was admitted with new onset tonic-clonic seizures and later developed aspiration pneumonia. She has a history of chronic diarrhea and was on chronic suppression therapy with vancomycin and flagyl. She was also on lasix drip for diuresis, which was uptitrated from 10-20 mg/hour.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She is on 2L NC oxygen and has improved respiratory status since transfer to the CCU.
* Cardiovascular: She has atrial fibrillation with a rate well-controlled in the 80s and is on IV metoprolol.
* Neurological: She has a recent change in mental status, likely multifactorial related to benzodiazepine, stroke, and respiratory status/hypercarbia on admission. She has anisocoria on exam and may have recent neb treatment.
* Renal: She is on lasix drip for diuresis and has a goal of 500cc/day. Her urine output has been negative ~200cc over the last few hours and is now responding.
* Gastrointestinal: She has a history of diarrhea and was on chronic suppression therapy with vancomycin and flagyl. Her diarrhea has stopped, and antibiotics were stopped this hospitalization.
* Skin: She has venous stasis ulcers on her legs, which may be related to venous stasis or autoimmune disorder.
* Nutrition: She is on crushed meds with apple sauce, nectar-thickened liquids, and lactose-intolerant.
* Laboratory results: Her WBC count is 11.7, Hct is 34.7, and Cr is 0.8.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia: The patient has aspiration pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure, sepsis, and multi-organ dysfunction.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation and severe aortic stenosis, which can lead to cardiac arrest, heart failure, and stroke.
* Neurological complications: The patient has a recent change in mental status, which can lead to seizures, stroke, and cognitive impairment.
* Renal complications: The patient is on lasix drip for diuresis, which can lead to electrolyte imbalance, dehydration, and acute kidney injury.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of diarrhea, which can lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and malnutrition.
* Skin complications: The patient has venous stasis ulcers, which can lead to infection, sepsis, and limb loss.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan can be developed:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust oxygen therapy as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with rate control and anticoagulation therapy.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust treatment as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust diuretic therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal function and adjust treatment as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's skin integrity and adjust treatment as needed.
* Consider adding zosyn to the patient's antibiotic regimen for possible aspiration pneumonia.
* Consider adding a rheum consult for the patient's venous stasis ulcers.
* Consult with a neurologist for further evaluation and management of the patient's recent change in mental status.
* Consult with a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of the patient's atrial fibrillation and severe aortic stenosis.
* Consider transferring the patient to the floor for further management and monitoring.

   admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures on [**2196-1-26**]. Patient had MS

   event, who subsequently went into Afib and flashed on the floor in the
   setting of holding her metoprolol and Lasix.
   # Volume overload: The patient has a history of severe AS and developed
   pulmonary edema in the setting of having her diuretics held on
   admission. Also noted to have RLL collapse on CXR. Overall her

   initially requiring humidified face mask, now on 2L NC o/n. UOP has

   required Lasix gtt for diuresis, but Lasix has now been transitioned to

   but patient is now afebrile. Was pan cultured. UA showed pyuria. No

   -continue vanc/cefepime/flagyl

   -f/u pending cultures

   her metoprolol. Restarted on IV metoprolol on arrival to the CCU.  Now
   s/p transition to PO metprolol.
   -continue PO metoprolol

   received AVR.
   - consideration being given for minimally invasive percutaneous valve
   replacement once medically stable, although it is not clear that the
   patient will be a candidate for this.

   have a focal lesion on head imaging.
   - ASA 81mg
   - f/u neuro recs
   - keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
   - avoid sedating meds
   - MRI when stable, per neuro recs

   - further head imagingn per neuro recs

   vanc/flagyl with last cx at [**Hospital **] rehab on [**2196-1-15**] negative. At that
   time, antibiotics were continued. However diarrhea has stopped so abx
   stopped this hospitalization.
   - c.diff negative
   - continue to monitor

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, severe aortic stenosis, and a history of colonic adenocarcinoma. The patient was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures and was found to have a focal lesion on head imaging.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has a history of severe aortic stenosis and developed pulmonary edema in the setting of holding her diuretics. She is currently on 2L nasal cannula oxygen and has improved greatly since transfer to the CCU.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is in atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. She was restarted on IV metoprolol on arrival to the CCU and has been transitioned to PO metoprolol.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, likely due to toxic or metabolic causes. She has a focal lesion on head imaging and is being treated with ASA and keppra for seizure prophylaxis.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of diarrhea and was treated with antibiotics. Her diarrhea has stopped, and antibiotics were stopped this hospitalization.
* Hematological: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and has stable hematocrit this morning.
* Wound care: The patient has leg ulcers, which are being managed with wound care. The etiology of the ulcers is unclear, but a rheumatology consult is planned following ICU stabilization.
* Nutritional: The patient is receiving tube feeds and has a nasogastric tube in place.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or respiratory failure due to the patient's history of severe aortic stenosis and pulmonary edema.
* Cardiovascular: Cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock due to the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and severe aortic stenosis.
* Neurological: Seizures, status epilepticus, or increased intracranial pressure due to the patient's focal lesion on head imaging and altered mental status.
* Gastrointestinal: Gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, or obstruction due to the patient's history of colonic adenocarcinoma and gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Hematological: Anemia, bleeding, or thrombocytopenia due to the patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and potential bleeding complications.

The patient's plan of care includes weaning off oxygen as tolerated, continuing PO metoprolol, and monitoring for signs of cardiac arrhythmias. The patient will also continue to receive tube feeds and will have a speech and swallow evaluation later this week. A rheumatology consult is planned following ICU stabilization to evaluate the etiology of the patient's leg ulcers.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, severe aortic stenosis, and colonic adenocarcinoma. She was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures and was found to have a mass change on her brain MRI, likely due to aspiration. She was treated with anticonvulsants and antibiotics. Her respiratory status has improved, but she still requires oxygen therapy and diuresis. She is at risk for aspiration pneumonia and has a history of chronic diarrhea and gastrointestinal bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient's history of aspiration and continued risk of aspiration due to dysphagia and tube feeding may lead to the development of aspiration pneumonia.
2. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged use of mechanical ventilation increases her risk of developing VAP.
3. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: The patient's use of insulin and glucose infusions may lead to the development of diabetic ketoacidosis if not properly managed.
4. Hyperkalemia: The patient's use of medications such as potassium-sparing diuretics and anticonvulsants may lead to hyperkalemia if not monitored closely.
5. Hypoglycemia: The patient's use of insulin and glucose infusions may lead to hypoglycemia if not properly managed.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory disease and prolonged use of mechanical ventilation increase her risk of developing respiratory failure.
7. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and cardiac disease increases her risk of developing cardiac arrest.
8. Sepsis: The patient's underlying medical conditions and use of antibiotics increase her risk of developing sepsis.
9. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and continued use of anticoagulants increase her risk of developing further gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Leg Ulcers: The patient's history of leg ulcers and continued use of anticoagulants increase her risk of developing further leg ulcers.

   86 y/o female with hx CAD s/p CABG, Afib, with severe AS s/p
   valvuloplasty, diastolic CHF, colonic adenocarcinoma, chronic c.diff,
   admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures, who subsequently flashed
   on the floor in the setting of holding lasix. Course complicated by
   subclinical seizures and deteriorating mental status, aspiration
   pneumonia, now w/respiratory acidosis and failure resulting in
   intubation ([**2-7**]), ARF, hypotension requiring phenylephrine. Being
   transferred to CCU at request of family and consulting cardiologist.
   .
   # Aortic Stenosis: Pt with known severe aortic stenosis s/p
   valvuloplasty in [**11-3**]. She was initially on the CCU service early in
   her hospitalization in the setting of flash pulmonary edema when her
   lasix were held. Now, she is intubated in the ICU and appears very
   fluid overloaded on physical exam. Pt has not responded to IV lasix.
   - holding on further diuresis
   - continue to closely monitor volume status
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Pt has good control of HR on beta blockade and
   digoxin.
   - continue metoprolol tartrate 25 mg TID
   - continue digoxin 0.0625 mg daily
   - coumadin was being held for ?supratherapeutic INR; INR subtherapeutic
   this AM; restart heparin gtt and coumadin
   .
   # Coronary Artery Disease: Pt is s/p CABG [**97**]/[**2188**].
   - continue metoprolol as above
   - continue aspirin 81 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg daily
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Per prior notes, pt has had seizures, loaded
   with dilantin and ativan PRN prior to admission with poor mental
   status. Despite loading dose continued to have sub clinical seziures on
   EEG. Medication regimen changed, currently on phenytoin and
   phenobarbitol.
   - continue phenytoin and Phenobarbital, adjusting per neuro recs
   - appreciate neuro recs
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Now, s/p trach.
   - trach in place
   - continue albuterol/atrovent PRN
   .
   # Pressor Requirement: Able to wean down this morning.
   - will lower MAP goal to try to keep pt off of pressors
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Still worsening. Per previous notes, renal
   believes that this is ATN. Recommend to not diurese or give IVF's.
   - holding on further diuresis, as above
   - continue to monitor fluid status otherwise

The patient's prognosis is considered to be poor, with a high risk of mortality due to the combination of underlying medical conditions and the severity of their illness.

   on the floor in the setting of holding lasix. Course complicated by
   subclinical seizures and deteriorating mental status, aspiration
   pneumonia, now w/respiratory acidosis and failure resulting in

   valvuloplasty in [**11-3**]. She was initially on the CCU service early in
   her hospitalization in the setting of flash pulmonary edema when her
   lasix were held. Now, she is intubated in the ICU and appears very
   fluid overloaded on physical exam. Pt has not responded to IV lasix.
   - holding on further diuresis
   - continue to closely monitor volume status
   .

   digoxin.
   - continue metoprolol tartrate 25 mg TID
   - continue digoxin 0.0625 mg daily

   this AM; restart heparin gtt and coumadin

   - continue metoprolol as above
   - continue aspirin 81 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg daily
   .
   # Altered Mental Status: Per prior notes, pt has had seizures, loaded
   with dilantin and ativan PRN prior to admission with poor mental
   status. Despite loading dose continued to have sub clinical seziures on
   EEG. Medication regimen changed, currently on phenytoin and
   phenobarbitol.
   - continue phenytoin and Phenobarbital, adjusting per neuro recs
   - appreciate neuro recs
   .
   # Respiratory Failure: Now, s/p trach.
   - trach in place
   - continue albuterol/atrovent PRN

   # Pressor Requirement: Able to wean down this morning.
   - will lower MAP goal to try to keep pt off of pressors
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: Still worsening. Per previous notes, renal

   - holding on further diuresis, as above
   - continue to monitor fluid status otherwise

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a complex medical history, including coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, severe aortic stenosis, and colonic adenocarcinoma. She was admitted with new onset tonic clonic seizures, which led to flash pulmonary edema, and subsequent deterioration in mental status, aspiration pneumonia, and respiratory acidosis, resulting in intubation. The patient is currently intubated in the ICU with a tracheostomy in place and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current vital signs include:

* Temperature: 37.4°C (99.3°F)
* Heart rate: 96 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 113/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 19 inspirations per minute (IPM)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 7.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 367 K/uL
* Creatinine: 3.3 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 16 mEq/L
* Sodium: 136 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.7 mEq/L
* Chloride: 100 mg/dL
* Glucose: 137 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 202 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.5 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions and complications include:

* Aortic stenosis with flash pulmonary edema
* Atrial fibrillation with good control of heart rate on beta blockade and digoxin
* Coronary artery disease with previous CABG
* Altered mental status with seizures, subclinical seizures, and poor mental status
* Respiratory failure with intubation and mechanical ventilation
* Acute renal failure with worsening creatinine and BUN levels
* Hypothyroidism with ongoing treatment with synthroid
* Fevers with completed antibiotic courses for pneumonia and urinary tract infection

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Further deterioration in mental status and respiratory failure
* Worsening acute renal failure and electrolyte imbalance
* Increased risk of bleeding due to anticoagulation therapy
* Infection, including ventilator-associated pneumonia and catheter-related bloodstream infection
* Cardiovascular complications, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest
* Nutritional deficiencies and electrolyte imbalance due to ongoing gastrointestinal losses and poor oral intake.
